Pioneer Experiences

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? All thought we would be happy except my brother as he said they wanted to farm.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? My family traveled together by train.

13. What means of transportation did you use? We used the train.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences.) There was very little that happened on our way only that we were a lonely family confronting and enduring many difficulties.

15. Where did you first stop when you arrived in Saskatchewan? Our first stop was at the town of Prince Albert.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? We settled near Prince Albert.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. Illinois and in Osmundset Park.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? Worked at various jobs in my father's store and then on my own and never did any other work except show work.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? All thought we were foolish except my brothers and they wanted us to come.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? We traveled with a group of friends who had heard about the land.

13. What means of transportation did you use? We used horse-drawn wagons and covered wagons.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the trail, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other events, etc.) We met many interesting people along the way, including a group of Indians who were friendly.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? We went right into town and built a house there.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? We settled in the area near the town of Prince Albert.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. We moved to Prince Albert and then to Prince Albert again.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? We worked at various jobs, but mostly farming.

19. How did you earn a living after coming to Western Canada? We continued farming and raising livestock.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home? How much did you change?

Then we went to church when they had it, too. We went to church every Sunday morning and home as early as they could get their shopping done.

If we may have come here, they could get their work off first and then they had a store as well. They could grow so many red roses named after our crew. She saw so many red roses growing on the side of hill, where they used to grow.

We came here from Brandon once or twice a year so when they had a store, they would come to the post office and they had a store as well. They would have to go to the city of Hull, where they lived.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

No, one moved away from right around here.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Thomas Findlay was a member of the Board of Education from 1911 to 1917.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "firsts" to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.
